description.text:
You have a big size printer and are looking for really strong bowden extruder? Then this one will suit you.

This is the first extruder of my extruder series. More upgraded versions will be released in the next few month.

modified version with filament-tracking-system:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:955370

The extruder is designed for use with 1.75mm filament.

Important: You need a NEMA 23 stepper with 5mm shaft! Usually they have 6.5 mm shaft. My rotor/shaft is edited on a lathe.

The extruder is designed to work with the great MK8 drive pully.

BOM:
4 pcs - nut DIN934 M5
1 pcs - nut DIN934 M4
3 pcs - screw DIN912 M5x16
1 pcs - screw DIN912 M5x35
1 pcs - screw DIN912 M4x30
1 pcs - round steel dia 6mm, 12mm
2 pcs - bearing 684ZZ
1 pcs - bearing 626ZZ
1 pcs - spring (standard print bed spring)
1 pcs - eye screw DIN444 M5x40
1 pcs - nut DIN466 M5
2 pcs - push fits M5 (4mm tube)
1 pcs - MK8 drive gear
1 pcs - NEMA 23 stepper (5mm shaft!!)
and finally: both printed parts

Please share your makes!

description.text:
Case for Project:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Create-an-alarm-system-and-visitor-counter-for-you/
This is a simple clip-on endstop trigger for the Z-stage endstops.

• Skeinforge (I had to configure Carve to Mesh Type: "Unproven Mesh")
  • Print
  • Clip the trigger on the Z-stage and adjust position.
    • When you found and tested the correct position, it might be a good idea to use a drop of hot glue to fix the clip. The clip design should be usable for the upper and lower endstops.

comments.text: Hi, have actually made two, after removing the ABP and going to the HBP I had to move the endstop down, which necessitated changing the mesh to have a much longer arm. I made it longer than it really needed to be but its much easier to cut a little off than to put a little more on!

comments.text:
Did you use black ABS?
As far as I know, white ABS (and other plastic like PLA) let too much light pass. You might want to try to paint the object or wrap it into something like aluminum foil.
If you're using black ABS, make sure your fill settings are ok. Any "holes" in the fill might spoil it...
comments.author: Guest

description.text:
Well this is an proof of concept so to speak. Not really a thing ;-). What i do here is generate scad files. I was playing with that thought for a while now. Because its a bit strange. I use one programming language (action-script 3.0 and flex in my case) to generate the other. In this case for the polygon method within openscad witch is powerfull but hard to read. So a made the visual helper for generation polygon call with a bit of extrusion Weird but it works what do you think mad or mad science ;) The small air app does not have any undo functionality and you can only draw on a grid, it was just to test something maybe i will add stuff to it ? should i ? http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0oSW9zlKsZ8 Update 14 Jun 2011:
Thanks for the great response but a bit of warning is in place the fxp source code is, well.. how do is say it.... very sloppy ;-) , just so you know build it 2 or 3 hours or so ( hack hack ) Update 13 Aug 2011:
Still working on it but not ready for its first release :-(
Some hints
  • Layers (one layer is one openscad module) each layer its own color
  • Adding and Deleting of Points and of course Moving points Splitting of segments
  • Curves (Maybe)
  • Save files (some json or xml) so you can save your work
  • Web based and AIR app
  • Etc Etc ;-)
    • Update 2 Aug 2012 :
    New version at
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13348
    Or
    http://www.protorabbit.nl/?p=32

• Install the air program (you need the air runtime from adobe)
  • Look at vid on youtube
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0oSW9zlKsZ8
  • Run the app draw some polygons
  • Save it
  • Open it in openscad
  • Check Automatic Reload reload and Compile in open scad
  • Make some more polygon and save
  • See openscad update (cool)
    • the scad files are some examples of what it generated
    the stl are the results from the scad files
    the fxp (is a zip) and can be imported into flash builder

title: Swamp boat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I always wanted to design and print a swamp boat.
Now it was time to realize it.

The boat consists of two parts, which are screwed together.
For sealing the whole thing is glued around the internal cable duct.

I took the motor and ESC out of my MHQ hovership, the receiver of my model car and the servo that just was lying around.

The boat has an integrated cable duct to "invisible" do all the wirering.

This Boat is also great to use with a FPV setup =)

Printer:

DIY RepRap

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I printed the rear and the front out of ABS and with 15% infill.
The control surfaces are printed with 20% infill.
All other parts are printed with 50% infill.

I have designed the swamp boat so all cables can run the hull in a cable duct.

The ESC and the reciever are covert in the front part of the boat.
The Battery is in the rear part to ceep the center of gravity behind the middle.

You can see it also on http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-printed-Swamp-boat/

To mount the control surfaces heat a pin needle and put it in the top and bottom around 3mm from the rounded edge.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing this RCWeinstadt. I'm in the process of printing this myself. I've seen a video on Youtube of this in action and it seemed the main concern was with it taking on water and sinking, as it seemed to be heavy. So I had an idea. If you look at the people who have made one, one of them mentioned using some foam on the back to prevent it from sinking. Do you think it would be possible to print the main parts (front and back) hollow? In doing so, perhaps we could insert foam and thus prevent it from sinking, even if it takes on water. Of course, this would mean a redesign of the front and back. Maybe they could be printed in two parts (bottom and sides as one and finally the top by itself). This would mean splitting the two main parts into two again. But it would save lots of filament as there wouldn't be a need for lots of infil/support. I don't know much about boats, or designing objects for 3D printing. So maybe this is a bad idea. But I thought I'd suggest it. Thanks!

author: RCWeinstadt

description.text:
I designed this in Wings 3D from scratch. I started with a cube
and built it up from there, finishing with smoothing and sculpting
for the rocks. Then I created a cavity for a tea light and took
out some of the windows so more light will shine through them.

I picked it because it's two of my favorite things to explore:
Castles and Caves.

It is 4.5 inches tall and 6.5 inches long.

It is designed for an LED tea light that is 1 1/8 inches
in diameter.

I printed it with 5% infill so the castle will have internal
support without affecting its transparency.
There is a cavity in the bottom for the tea light. I used
a few external supports for the cavity.

The classic spiked pigskin.

Made using a file from MWM's (http://www.thingiverse.com/mwm/about) Oklahoma Sooners logo bolo tie (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:342413), and spiked-up in TinkerCad.

title: Transport screw workaround for wade extruder

description.text:
I had some difficulties to get the wade screw ready properly. I tried the tap-method but was not successful so I decided to try the teeth version. This "thing" will show a method to get a desired amount of teeth into the bolt and how to divide the surface of this screw into exactly same sized teeth. You will find all about the wade extruder here:
http://reprap.org/wiki/Wade's_Geared_Extruder ...and here on Thingiverse:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794 Can actually also be used on other similar extruder designs.

Disc:
  • Print the PDF file for 16 divisions (this number works fine for me...)
  • Glue onto thick piece of cardboard
  • Cut disc out and make centric hole with Ã˜ 8mm
    • Wade Screw (M8 screw or piece of threaded rod can be used):
  • Take your screw and mark the position where theets are desired on the screw
  • Screw the disc you made on one end and secure with nut
  • Mount into your drill press
  • Fix your dremel onto the table of the drill press
    • this is a bit tricky.. I did it by clamping it to some support jigs. I leave the table of the drill press lose (not screwed in position) hanging on lowest level. like this I can centre the dremel once on my wade-screw and each time I pull the table to the screw it will hit the same position.
  • Fix a wire on the drill press to point to one of the divisions on your disc (pay attention that it is not loose!)
  • Start the dremel and pull table to the screw. Move drill chuck up and down a bit to get the teeth all over the desired area
  • After first cut, push table off the screw and turn (by hand) the drill chuck until it lines up with the next division
  • Repeat step 6 & 7 until you have cut all teeth.
    • Please mind: This screw design need well tightened nuts because it tries to unscrew itself out of the extruder. Use two nuts or a locknut to fix it in your extruder.

author: TheHotEndChannel

description.text:
An addicting toy-weapon that shoots rubber bands at the rate of your choice. You can quickly change your barrel and a single clip(barrel) can easily carry 72 rubber bands. Furthermore, "T-800" is written at the side of the toy so it looks cooler. You can find a vido of myself shooting some rubber bands with a junky-prototype version of the real thing. The only piece that is still in construction is the barrel, as it can get stuck while firring.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NmIA7zunx6I

If you want to use the gun, you need to attach a small rope or string(floss, per example), to the sideway holeon the barrel. You then make a loop around the barrel with the string. Then, you attach rubber bandson the barrel so they are as stretched as possible. You then repeat the loop and the rubber band positionnement until you are out of rubber band, or only have about 30 centimeters of string left. Finally, you attach the other end of the string to the trigger. Then you can assemly the pieces.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't matter
When you will have printed the pieces, all you need to do is to assembly those pieces like shown on the the first image available of my project.

Project Name

Elastic Minigun

Overview & Background

In this project, you will learn how you can mix 3D design to one of your favorite activites. As a matter of fact, me and my friends often play airsoft nd nerf wars on weekends, but also rubber band shooting at school. I recently decided I would mix our fun time, and create a rubber band minigun, for our weekend activities. With a bit of creativity, you can achieve anything.

Objectives

With your participation in my project, I will keep upgrading my model for you until it has no tecnical failures. I am opened to yours ideas and would like to work with you. Furthermore, you will be able to learn a lot about plane surfaces and flow modeling, when you will open the .ipt files I left for you guys.

Audiences

The people who will understand my drawings only need the equivalent of 100 hours of Autodesk Inventor. For this project, I used the 2016 version of Inventor, so you will need the same to open the files I placed down for you guys.

Subjects

This project is relevant in subjects like math and physics.

Skills Learned

I have always used a lot of planes surfaces along my pieces. By viewing my parts, you will be able to learn a lot about plane surfaces and flow modeling, when you will open the .ipt files I left for you guys.

Lesson/Activity

As I really like 3D design, I already made the whole design. All you need to do is to download the .stl files and print them. If you are using some rubber bands that have a diameter wider than 2 centimeters, download the .ipt file for the barrel and extend the first extrusion's lenght to your rubber band's need.

P.S.: The rubber bands have to be stretched to the point where you fear they will break.

Duration

The time completion for a project like this is about two hours when you know exactly what you are trying to do. With the brainstorming and the mistakes made while working, I would say this project might take around 20 consecutive hours

Preparation

The Autodesk Inventor has it's interface well planned. The level of experience needed to make a task is always identifiable by the position this task has in the modeling and drawing interface. The more an option is placed to the left, the easier it is, and vice-versa. Therefore, a student who would want to understand completely what is in front of him would have to master half of each modeling section of the interface.

References

If you want to optimise your machines power, a quick research on the web about your rubber band's maximal lenght would minimize the possibility of mistakes.

Rubric & Assessment

A passing student would have created a functionning barrel, able to shoot at least one rubber band per second. Students with grades higher than the average will have designed a support for the barrel. The top tier students will have made a trigger to pull the string, this trigger being also held by the support

Like to fly?
Print my flybox

This is a simple (rather simple, was my first dip into Perl) script to download and organize a Thing, placing it's various parts into ./thing/
It also outputs a URL shortcut to the page on thingiverse.

Download (I don't think it'll work on windows, but maybe with cygwin. The URL shortcuts are Linux-style for the moment) Syntax:
thingget \<thingnumber>|\<thingurl>|\<thingaddress> Example:
To grab the Head of Stephen Colbert (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9104)
thingget 9104
thingget http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9104
thingget www.thingiverse.com/thing:9104

I designed this sponge holder to allow for better air drying and help to minimize bacterial growth. I use 3mm filament for struts and rivet the ends neatly with a woodburning kit. To attach to a wall, I used thumbtacks or screws, but silicone would work well for tile.
http://youtu.be/0JjWi9Too6o

Designed to print with no support. Use a woodburner or soldering iron and some 3mm filament or plastic rod to make rivets on both ends. The Soap snap is attached the same way but using a small length of filament.

UPDATE 19-07: After I realized that my "ventilator" is actually good at transforming wind to mechanical energy, I decided to print a "bearing" of sorts to test exactly how good. The print quality of the wheel isn't that great, since then I've changed to ABS (NuNus Blue). I made two new parts, a hex interface and a simple bracket to hold the assembly. I've added the files in case someone wants to try it. Next step will a small gearbox, just for the fun of it.

UPDATE 17-07: So the part printed this morning, sadly while I was working late last night I've flipped the fin direction, so it'll move air only when turning left. Throughput isn't great, but I suppose if it's in a casing it'll compensate. I'll try to make a better version this weekend.

A small side project for my neighbor, who got a small desktop cooler from a magazine. Just going to try and make it better. Much more info and designs to follow

description.text:
This paddle boat is comes with either a screw or a pulley wheel to wrap the rubber band around, depending on the width of your rubber band.
It has two sections to hold pennies.
Glue is required to attach the wheel to the axis, the 2nd cylinder to the axis, and to attach the corkscrew/pulley wheel to the axis.
These three objects are other's that i used in my design:
screw- Thesaint7811
pulley wheel- alisonleanne
washer- Petehagoras

I started with body, creating a box with and open top.Then I added 4 hollow balls to the body. The holes on the top are there to release any of the resin that gets caught inside. I then created the wheels using rectangular prisms and cylinders. The axis is shaped strangely so the wheels would have a better grip. Using the subtract tool, i created holes in the body of the boat and with copies of the axis, made a hole in one of the wheels. The other wheel i attached to the axis. I then added a hook to the front of the body. I used washers, a pulley wheel and a corkscrew from other people's projects (listed in sources) and resized them for my project. The corkscrew and the pulley wheel are interchangeable depending on the width of the rubber band. Glue required to attach the wheel to the axis and to attach the corkscrew/pulley wheel to the axis.
By suggestion, I have added a cylinder on each side of the wheel to fill out the holes so it would spin more smoothly.

comments.text: it would be better to have a cylinder axle to allow for better rotation and have a odd shape like that only where the rubber band engine sits. getting my printer soon and this is definitely on my list!

description.text:
Brackets for mounting micro switches on the Shapeoko 3 - updated Z-limit bracket.

Original Z-bracket could interfere with motor, updated it it prevent such issue.

Printed: 3 shells, 12.5% infill, PLA. Printed Z bracket with support, none needed/used for the others.
Used M4 hardware for bottom of XY and X brackets to clear the roller.
I obtained my switches some time ago, and regrettably can't tell you where to get these specific ones. 123d files included to modify for your switch etc...

comments.text: Well I printed the XY bracket V1 and I'm not so convinced about it. The X switch is at a position where if you move Z axis down at the X home position, a part of the Z plate bumps it... I think positioning the X switches at the back of the Z axis is better than at the end on the X axis itself... but it's only my opinion... may-be I missed something obvious here... Anyway, keep sharing your great ideas like this one, it's great !

https://www.3dhubs.com/chicago/hubs/kwallnation

author: kwallnation

description.text: This was my first attempt at converting a 2-D picture file to an STL file. I'm brand new to printing and very excited about providing this technology to my after-school group and classroom students.

I made this stand so that i could better skype with people from my galaxy note 3. I made this stand myself because i could not find one that would print within a 100^3mm print area. If anyone finds this useful let me know :). I may redo it soon to include a space for a charge cord.

Another transformer. I was going to wait till I had finished detailing everything, but I figured the sooner it's released the sooner someone can start having fun with it. Files in SW2011. Seeing how it's taken me several months to get this far don't hold your breath on me finishing any time soon. Edit 1: Stripped out all detailing so the files are a blank "canvas" and added STL and STEP. Edit 2: http://www.thingiverse.com/tbuser has designed some snap together pins. Now I just need to apply them to the model. Check out his design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10288. Edit 3: Superseded by V3.

Most of the joints are only roughed in. I want to make this thing snap together without extra hardware. Also, all of the parts have zero clearance so they won't work together in reality without some modding. Some of the parts will need support material in their current form. Notes:
All but the head joint are pegs/pins. The model shows them at their max ID/OD so if you want to take a swing at modeling a snap joint cut away from the pegs and add to the holes. If someone wants to start experimenting with snap joint design and tolerance for this I would appreciate it as I don't have a printer at the moment. Getting the tolerance right so the joints move but can be posed might be difficult.

title: ATX power supply cutout, screw down mounting bracket

description.text:
A mounting bracket for ATX power supplies.
Designed to be minimalistic in its use of material, yet strong enough to stop the power supply slipping and sliding off a working surface. Also designed to fit the smaller build area of a Printrbot Simple Metal (if no skirt used).

Ideal to mount the ATX power supply in vertical orientation and allows for fixings to screw into base board or similar.

Example shown, printed with no supports using PLA.

Just fits inside the Printrbot Simple Metal build area if Skirt set to zero in Cura (or your slicer of choice).

Screw down onto a base and use short length (don't short electric stuff in the power supply) M3 screws into the power supply chassis threaded holes.

comments.text: If anyone wants variations on this, I don't mind giving it a go.

This is a vacuum cleaner impeller for an upright Bissell vacuum cleaner. It is a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6095. You can tinker with the dimensions to fit your vacuum. Have fun!

https://applemountain.etsy.com

extrusion_width = 0.4
cylinder_height = 60

This is a modification to the original E3D-Online v6 hotend fan duct. It mounts exactly the same way as the original. This duct extends just a bit farther down to accommodate a 40 mm (4 cm ) case fan. It also extends outward and additional 5 mm to clear any obstacles and minimize back pressure.

Get rid of the small 30 mm fan and put something with a little more power and life in its place. It is not designed to center the fan. It is placed on the heatsink fins exactly in the same position as the OEM fan duct.

Print using Nylon, PET or ABS. Nylon and PET will be less brittle than ABS and more flexible for snapping in place over the heat sink fins. Print face down with a brim to prevent warping, also allow your slicer of choice to add supports to the underside.

author: Agame

description.text:
Got sick of my standalone spool holder getting dragged around. This one clips to the top deck. I tried to get minimal overhang in both the x and z directions. The aesthetic is "harp wishing it was rims."

Prints as 3 separate pieces; I couldn't finagle both clips to fit on the bed. Haven't put it to the test yet, so could get some small modifications in the near future. The two clips are asymmetrical and flat on one side. Surprisingly sturdy with low infill.

Basic clip design taken from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:741364

comments.text: I used Sketchup to lay the sides down on their flat side and rotate them to the correct angle for the M3D to read them upon load, since the in-program rotation wasn't doing the job.  Is there a way for me to upload or send them to you?
comments.author: Zerdath

comments.text:
Oh my. Yeah, printing it as-is is a bad time. The M3D GUI is also a little weird, in that the rotation axes don't quite rotate the object around the eponymous axes.
For the left side, rotate to Y=90, Z=-90, then right-click and drag to rotate the entire piece so that it lays diagonally across the print bed (otherwise it doesn't fit laying down)
For the right side, same thing but with Z=90.
Hope that helps for future prints!
comments.author: HebrewThunder

comments.text: I made it, but M3D imports as a vertical object, standing straight up on its tip.  I found turning it to lay flat on the bed for printing was very hard for me to do. I ended up with support material to scrape off.  Too new to this to know how to fix.

title: Botsauto munt of jeton of penning (bumper car coin)

description.text:
These coins fit in (Belgian) bumper cars. There are coins of different sizes around, you can customize your own coins, see the reference picture in the gallery for some known measurements! The provided STL is for a coin with a 35mm diameter.  
Be warned, you may print these (this is not real money so this is not counterfeiting) but you cannot use these without permission of the owner of the bumper cars, that would legally be considered as premeditated stealing!  
This thing is meant as a thought experiment, to ponder the legal limits of 3D printed objects.
Print with support.

author: daniel_rubenstein

description.text: It is a clock

Look at your hands.  
Hands are complex tools that grant humans a superpower, the power to transform imagination into reality.  The power of our hands is unlimited.  We can use them to throw a ball, climb a tree, or build a tool.  
Not everyone is fortunate enough to have two hands.  
Robohand is an open source tool created to help restore the superpowers of humans who are missing the fingers from their hand.  The original version was created by Richard Van As and Ivan Owen.

The Snap-Together edition of Robohand is a simplification of the original Robohand.  It lacks the rugged durability of the original, but is much faster and easier to build.  This snap-together version is primarily an experimental platform to help people understand the mechanics of Robohand.  I also hope it will serve as a catalyst  for future development, and inspire others to pick up the project where I have left off.  
Full Assembly Instructions can be found in the Instructions PDF   
Source files are in SketchUp format and are available in: Robohand_Snap_Fittings.skp

comments.text:
Owning a printer is a big expense. If you want some parts printed, and resources to help you out, get in touch with the folks at e-Nable. We will print your hand parts for free.
The Snap-Together Robohand is a brilliant development of the work of Ivan Owen and Richard Van As, by Michael Curry. Michael incorporated the snap-pin design into this cable-driven prosthetic device. That said, there are later designs that do a better job of fitting to a person. The Talon Hand, Cyborg Beast and Ody Hand are being fitted to people with good results.
If you can make it, come to "Prosthetists Meet Printers" at Johns Hopkins Hospital on September 28. Free admission, and your nephew will get a free device. He should bring family members to help him assemble his device.

comments.text:
ehuels is correct-- the design is effectively backwards. The fingers should grasp as the wrist extends. I think correcting this would involve routing the cables below the axis of rotation of the "wrist" joint.
Modifying the knuckle bridge would make the grasp more natural, but natural grasp is also due to the fact that fingers don't flex parallel to each other; they all point toward the base of the thumb. In addition, they have different radii of curvature (the small finger flexes more tightly than the ring which flexes more than the middle). Adjusting the knuckle bridge to accomodate this & individualizing the fingers to flex different degrees would make a much better grasp. Also, "fattening" the fingers to decrease the space between them would make the hand more functional.
However, I think the best function would be to achieve a pinch. This would involve getting the thumb to rotate around to meet the tips of the fingers, instead of just flexing.
Don't know if these are feasible, but would love to print one if you can design it....
-aarongrand
comments.author: aarongrand

comments.text: Just printed and assembled first RoboHand.  It was extremely simple.  Thanks for making this available.  This is for use by my son.  One modification I made on the suggestion of our OT, was to mount the bridges upside down. This is the natural movement in order to grasp; i.e. wrist in the up position for grasp, wrist in the down position to release.  This does cause binding on the thumb string, so I will be looking to modify for that.  Also, I would also like to modify the knuckle bridge.  I think if it was curved, instead of flat, the fingers would come together, more like a natural grasp.  Will update if I am successful.

A double-barreled blowgun with a 24-shot magazine for Buzzbee darts (Like Nerf darts, but cheaper, more durable, and slightly shorter). Just tilt back, rotate the mouthpiece, and you've got 2 shots ready to blow. WILL NOT WORK AS-IS WITH NERF BRAND DARTS!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GHJuYFLWkf8

1. Print 1 each of the .stl files. You may need to adjust the hole fit for your individual printer--a .stp file is provided for those that have a CAD system to edit the parts.

  2. Cut 2 pieces of thinwall 1/2" PVC pipe to a length of 28"

  3. Cut 2 pieces of schedule 40 1/2" PVC pipe to a length of 28", and bevel the inside of one end. This will be where the dart enters.

  4. File the top of the dart holder drum so it's smooth enough to superglue, then glue that surface to the bottom of the mouthpiece, lining up the holes as best you can.

  5. Drill out the center hole to 1/4" as needed, then put a 6" long 1/4-20 screw through the mouthpiece, dart holder drum, and the magazine holder drum. The smooth bottom surfaces of the dart holder drum and the magazine holder drum should be pressed against each other. The head of the screw should be on the mouthpiece side.

  6. Put a 1/4-20 nut loosely on the screw. Tighten it down so that the dart holder drum and magazine holder drum are gently pressed against each other.

  7. Put a dab of superglue just above the nut from step 6, then put another 1/4-20 nut on the screw. Tighten the nuts against each other, but not against the printed parts. At the end of this step, the magazine holder drum should be pressed against the rest of the assembly, but not so hard that it's difficult to turn.

  8. Insert the barrels (28" of 1/2" schedule 40 PVC pipe) bevel-side first into the magazine holder drum. They should be diagonal from each other.

  9. Insert the magazines (28" of 1/2" thinwall PVC pipe) into the magazine holder drum. They should be diagonal from each other as well.

  10. Place the front magazine holder on the barrels/magazines at the front of the blowgun. Press everything together.

  11. Add a strip of rubber or other flexible material in the provided slot to create a dart-retaining flap. I hot-glued a couple strips of rubber in there, but you could achieve the same effect with cardboard or folded paper if need be.

  12. Put some orange tape on the tip of this to prevent anyone from getting butthurt about toy gun ID.

To load the magazines, push darts past the flaps into the thinwall PVC magazines. With this length, you should be able to fit 11 into each of the two magazine tubes. To load darts into the firing chambers/ barrels, just tilt back and rotate the mouthpiece/dart holder drum 90 degrees. To fire, just blow each of the two mouthpiece holes in front of the barrels.

I printed it in white PLA with a supports touching the buildplate. I also sunk the part into the printed a few mm, and stopped the print a little early to give it flat features on the top and bottom. title: Taz4 Enclosure 120mm Fan Fume Filter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This will filter the air inside the printer enclosure by the use of a carbon filter.

This complements my Taz4 Enclosure (thing 689852) design.

While this is design is functional, I would recommend my other design 3d Printer Filter as it uses an off the shelf car filter and has worked better at filtering for me.

I mounted it up high in the back of the enclosure so that it will filter the hot air and recirculate it down along the back to normalize the temperature inside.

Included are files for the whole pieces and the larger pieces split into three. I found it easier to print the split pieces due to the size and length of the print.

If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

Either print the whole pieces,

  • EffBody.stl
  • EffBottomPlate.stl
  • EffFanMount.stl

Or print the split pieces

  • EffBodySplitCenter.stl
  • EffBodySplitLeft.stl
  • EffBosySplitRight.stl
  • EffBottomPlateSplitCenter.stl
  • EffBottomPlateSplitLeft.stl
  • EffBottomPlateSplitRight.stl
  • EffFanMount.stl

You will need to provide a 120mm computer fan, the 12v power supply to connect to the fan, and a means to glue to the pieces together.

I printed in ABS, so I mixed scrap ABS with acetone (1:2 ratio) to create a thick ABS glue in the same color. This works really well with ABS.

If you printed the split pieces, glue them together first as their component pieces and let them cure until hard. I gave them another coat over the seams to smooth them out and also along any cracks or splits.

Make sure your fan screws onto the fan mount, then glue the fan mount into place and let it cure until hard.

The bottom I mount by using 3M double sides foam tape (20 lbs. stuff) as its thin and rubbery. Just a little along the near fan, and few other spots. This will allow you to remove easy enough if you need to in the future.

I mounted the completed fume filter in the upper center of my enclosure using the same 3m double sided tape.

Bracket used to extend custom drone assemblies and add dihedral for stability.

It’s a test of buoyancy to see who can return their boat the quickest.
The buoyancy boat was specially made to return to its original send off point.

As soon as you place the boat onto the water the buoyancy lever starts taking in water. Once it reaches full capacity the lever swings down reversing the paddle direction.

The challenge: Weight the boat using pennies in the penny trays on the boat to add more displacement to the boat.
See how fast you can return the boat after it reaches a distance of 20 feet.

The more weight on the boat will cause the buoyancy lever to switch faster therefore reversing the engine sooner but be careful, the more weight means more water displacement making the boat move slower. Find the magic medium and beat your friends in this fun science game.

All parts click together. Its easy to print and assemble with the PDF instructions.

Watch the YouTube video: https://youtu.be/fxd72qmHTqM
More videos to come...

I was visiting Portland and admiring the great freighters that passed by hourly wondering about the bilge water being pumped out of the ships and wondering where that water must have come from.
The stability of the ship lies in its buoyancy displacement. The more water it takes in the more stability it has.
My cousin and I used to sit along the pear and call out the countries of these grand freighters that muscled along the shore. As they got closer to port they began rising out of the water while pumping water out from their tanks. The science behind buoyancy fascinated me and inspired me to build this boat.

Please read the PDF instructions for details.
All links for parts can be found in the instructions.

The Paddle Boat uses 2 water bottles on either side and requires one 3V~6V electric motor. There is a universal engine mount that can accept almost all electric motors under 2" diameter.

You will need 2 switches.
Don’t forget some basic wire and 2 or 4 AA batteries depending how much power your DC motor needs.
The assembly of the electronics is easy, just follow the diagram in the instructions booklet.

comments.text: Finally got my print done.  This one was a challenge.  The radius you put around the hole made this a bit tricky.  I ended up reducing the heat like you suggested and also reduced the speed and added support for printing the bottom section.  I had a few failed prints, but I am also new to this printer and never had to deal with supports.  So my recommendation for you is to reduce or eliminate the radius on the ends of the hole.  I would also think putting a bit of a radius on the stem of the "T" connector on top would help with twisting it onto the case slot.  I got it in with a little force and no big deal, but just a thought.  With that said, I loved the challenge and it really pushed me to understand my printer a bit more.  Now I also have not finished my dual fan setup and I think that would have helped a lot.  Finished part looks really good and no cleanup was needed (besides removing the supports) for it to slide together perfectly.  Love the part.  Had a lot of fun figuring out how to print it (rookie).  Thanks again for sharing a nice tool free way to replace the zip tie.  It will make life easier when taking the top off and on.  I can't wait to see what designs you come up with next.  Keep up the great work.
comments.author: EthanNewhouse

My 'press fit' has started sliding around and it almost came open once.  Nothing a little tape to take up the slack won't fix.  The parts fit perfectly together.

title: Fidget Star
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Open, close, repeat. One way it's a box and the other way it's a star. Then a box. Then a star. Repeat the repeat.

This hinged print-in-place model is a remix of the Fidget Cube. It 3D prints fully assembled, in one piece, folded up! A snub version is also included for those who like the old school fidget.

For the design geeks: Thanks to Greg Knapp, who used Blender to fold up the original Fidget Cube model and print it as a closed cube. His YouTube video inspired me to do the same thing in OpenSCAD code so that the Fidget Cube could be printed as a closed cube. The remix gave me the opportunity to make the snub side of the fidget a more interesting star shape.

For the math geeks: The "star" is a stellated rhombic dodecahedron, and this model makes up half of a Yoshimoto cube.

UPDATE: @David_Mussaffi made a great video of a Fidget Star 3D printing in the closed position, check it out! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GGq2zIDUaYg

UPDATE: @MosaicManufacturing has made a fantastic Multi-Color Fidget Star and printed it with their cool Palette color-enabling 3D printer attachment!

=====

Twitter: twitter.com/mathgrrl
Hacktastic blog: www.mathgrrl.com/hacktastic
Shapeways geekhaus store: www.shapeways.com/shops/mathgrrl

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

File descriptions:

  • fidget_star_standing_15_48.stl and fidget_snub_standing_15_48.stl are medium-sized models that print standing up, unfolded. One is a stellated rhombic dodecahedron on the fun side, and the other is a cube with corners cut down.

  • fidget_star_closed_15_48.stl and fidget_snub_closed_15_48.stl are like the above, but print closed up.

  • fidget_star_standing_30_2_50.stl is a larger model with 30mm cubes, so a folded height of about 60mm and a standing height of about 120mm. It takes about 4-5 hours to print.

If you choose one of the "closed" designs then it will print folded up, with the cube side out. After printing you'll be able to open it up and see the star. If the closed version doesn't work on your printer, then try the "standing" assembly instead, which prints while folded open. If you need to make other adjustments to size or clearances, try the Customizer version.

If you want to print this model larger or smaller, then don't just scale up or down the model as a whole. Instead, use the Cusomizer to change the cube height, but preserve the hinge size.

I've found that a hinge clearance of .48 is optimal for MakerBot Replicator 3D printers. Other printers may need more or less hinge clearance. If your hinges are fused together, first make sure that you've turned supports OFF. After that you might try adjusting hinge clearance.

After printing, horizontal hinges will sometimes have some sag underneath; clipping this off before attempting to open the model will help increase your chances of success.

The Challenge has begun!
atartanian vs. mathgrrl --1 design per week, winner take all

Thanks to atartanian for challenging me to get back on track and post a design a week. Speaking of tracks, check out his entry for this week: Cutomizable Flexible Toy Train Tracks. Let us know what you think in the comments!

Read more at Hacktastic:
http://mathgrrl.com/hacktastic/2015/07/week-1-battle-entry-fidget-star-vs-flexible-train-tracks/

Don't have a 3D printer, or want something fancy printed for you? We don't have Fidget Stars in our print-to-order store yet, but we have other cool stuff you can check out:

comments.text: The answer is no. No it does not print well on a Robo. Although I'm not sure if this is due to the printer's capabilities or my own ignorance of optimal settings. The only hinges that work well for me are the ones that printed on the top of the closed model. The ones on the sides came out either kind of rough (if perpendicular to printer bed) or completely blobby and unusable (if parallel to printer bed). In the bottom ~10 layers of the cubes that sit on top in the closed model, you can see the strands of filament all blobbed up instead of laying down in nice neat layers. It was a nice quick print so I'll probably keep trying but would love to hear any tips on what might have gone wrong. I'm using PLA with the medium quality preset (0.2 mm layer height and I think 15 or 25% infill).

Definitely need NO supports though - if you had supports on then that support would fill in those gaps and fuse the model together. comments.text: they keep breaking at the hinges. Using Makerbot Replicator Can you tell me how to adjust hinge size to try and fix the problem.
comments.author: ace1mc

comments.text: First make sure you are printing at .2mm layer height with NO supports.  Then, before snapping, cut off any droopy bits that are hiding under the hinges; specifically, at each horizontal hinge there may be a small droop of filament underneath the ledge of the hinge, where it printed outward without support.  If that doesn't work then open the model in the Customizer and try increasing the "hinge_clearance" parameter from the default .48 to something a tiny bit larger, such as .5. Good luck and let me know if that helps!

This is the miniature for my Randomly-rolled custom Character Race in my friend's Wayfarer Campaign.

I rolled for a total of 5 adaptions, in addition to the total of 29 tentacles for locomotion and grasping: Bizzare, Concordant, Defensive, Morphic, Robust.

It seems that I rolled up a mobile Cactus who's roots can weave together to create more complex forms! I call the character: Mr Spynes. I ended up not modelling the tendrils, and put him in a pot... (The rest of the group don't know he's not immobile... until they read this post... It's been fun to have it move throughout the ship 'on it's own' and only interact with the environment with it's tendril roots when no-one's looking...)

PARLAT
TECH LEVEL 5 (Iron-Age)
"Although looking like a Bizzare Prickly Plant in their native form, the Parlat have 'roots' that they use as both manipulators and locomotion. The scarce resources and low spawn rates on their desolate homeworld have forced the Parlat to evolved a complex trading society remarkable for it's lack of any central government. With recent mining operations on their world, many of their number have been found as 'stowaways' on transport ships off world".
ATTRIBUTE ADJUSTMENTS
STR+0, DEX+0, BUL+0, AGI+0, END+6,
REA+0, PER+0, WIL+0, CRE-0, CHA+9
TRAITS
Disease Resistance 9, Regeneration 1d10-1, Shapeshifter 9, Skill Adept (Intimidate) +1, Skill Adept (Romance) +4, Tentacles x29,
PERSONALITY ADJUSTMENTS
Openness +2, Conscientiousness +0. Extroversion +8, Agreeableness +4, Neuroticism +0

title: Dual Fan Donut Shroud for Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

description.text:
1st off, this is a work in progress, and I have not printed the full thing yet, just parts of it. Once I do, I'll upload the pictures.

Update 8/6/2015: My measurements for the MK7 extruder assembly was off a bit. Fixed that, and in turn had to fix the the other 2 parts to fit.

Update: I've uploaded the 2 clamp version. It will clamp on the motor and the hot end fan. Still have not printed them to check fit.

This should make bridging with PLA a lot more feasible. That's the idea anyways. Print it in ABS with no supports @ .2 or .3 layer height. I have printed the donut part successfully. I have to test the fan funnels next.
I used Repetier Host to print. Slic3r prints were not as good as Cura. It's designed to be used with 40mm fans. I'm currently working on changing the mounting to be a little easier to put on and take off. It will basically have 2 "clamps", on in the back, as in this design, and one in the front. I will upload it as soon as I'm done with it.

P.S. with .3 layer height, Cura estimated about 2 hours, but will probably take about 2:30 or 2:45. At .2 layer height, Cura estimated 3 hours, so it will take about 4.

Print with ABS at .2 or .3 layer height with no support and 20% to 30% fill. Mount 2 40mm fans blowing into the donut and wire them together. The fan bolt holes are M3 and the clamp is M4 (or 6-32 allthread).

I have not printed the full part yet, just parts of it. Once I do, I'll upload the pictures.

comments.text: Just interested what kind of speed you can use to get this in 4hours? In my best settings it takes estimated 11,5hours

remixed_from.author: Cola
remixed_from.title: E3D V6 Hot end Mount for Ormerod

description.text:
This mount is for the Ormerod 2 (528.3). The hotend was reconstructed from their drawings (Near enough). Part 546 was used to check distances. It should be tolerant to slight variations in the construction of the E3d. This is a modification of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:586189 as I first printed it but had to modify part 546 to correct height (As there must be a different between the Ormerod 1 and 2). You'll probably have to re-zero your Z axis.

You should be able to use existing parts, I have made the holes on the "Nozzle" mount smaller to allow the bolts to bite in (I didn't have enough long bolts to use the nuts with).

I've tested with PLA and ABS fine.

You can also find this on Onshape.

Ever want to make custom heroclix without having to sacrifice a dial? Now you can with this dial! I have tried my best to improve on the design and make it easier to customize.

comments.text: Hi there! I like your file, however I don't play clix or actually needed for heroclix but for another use. I need a tracker that clicks down my actions from 0 to 12 maybe 16, I don't know if clix can turn that many times or not, but could you help me with something like that? Also I know the opening on clix is that odd shape because you need to see the 4 stats but is it possible to just make it a symmetric opening shape like a rectangle or maybe even a circle? I only need to see one number (sometimes 2 digits long) hope im not asking for too much, thanks
comments.author: rrleonc689

comments.text:
I think I can actually help you out with some advice.
A typical heroclix dial has up to 12 clicks to display information on. If you're looking for a dial to turn up to 16, you could create a dual click base by joining 2 of these circular bases together, giving you a max of 24 clicks. I'm not versed in 3d printing just yet, so I couldn't tell you how to actually do that, but that is my best suggestion for your question, whether you've gotten an answer or not already.
comments.author: rrleonc689

comments.text: Hey there im tried printing the two parts seperately on their flat side with 100% infill. It clips together but does not turn seems like the inside lip of the cap is too tigth. Got any tips for me. Thx

comments.text: I'll eventually redesign the base, but I've been experimenting with printing the top piece .2 to .5 mm larger. It should open up the tolerance a bit more.

comments.text: That's the idea, lol. I want to help as many people as possible when building custom clicks. When assembling, you may need a vice to clamp the parts together. I'd recommend about 50% infil with PLA just to get a strong part.
comments.author: aceoswords

comments.text:
Have you made one?
I cannot get it work, nor PLA neither ABS.
Thanks!
comments.author: jorgerobles

comments.text: How have you been trying to print it? In your slicer settings you need to divide the object(s) into separate parts and print each part one at a time (base and top seperately). It will require a lot of clean up once your done printing and will need significantly precise sanding/finishing once you get the parts printed so that you don't take too much off. I also reccommend printing at the highest resolution possible for your machine because of the small raises and dips in the respective parts. it will take a longer time but when its done it should work alright. Also, take EXTRA care to clean out the inside lip of the top part of the dial.
comments.author: jorgerobles

comments.text:
Well, I printed them on separate parts, 0.2mm layer height, with the cap upside down (the dial window touches heatbed), but clearances are so tight I could not snap them together. Original heroclix use a kind of outer slots that allow the perimeter to flex for snapping.
Anyways, I will try with 0.1mm layer height, thanks!
comments.author: azurial

comments.text: Ah yeah. When I tested it, the print really wouldn't turn out without 100% infill to keep it from snapping when pulling it off of the bed or getting it on the base. You could try putting a few slots in by cutting it down on either side with a Dremmel or a saw off some sort, but be careful if you go that route. You don't want to take too much off because there's a good chance it'll break when joining the two sides.
comments.author: jorgerobles

description.text: This is another shoe clip for the Nike+ Sensor. I used the design from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48605 to print this for a friend. I found the holes very thight and so I decided to design a new one. I also added the 123dx file so that you can edit it in 123 Design for your own adaptations.

Printed on a Flashforge Creator in ABS, medium settings using Simplify3D. No issue with the bridges. No raft needed. Hotbet at 110°C and Hotend at 250°C. On a glass plate. Used glue stick like for PLA and remained on the plate. When it cooled out, the part removed easily.

title: Joy Division's Unknown Pleasures
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Joy Division's iconic cover by Peter Saville representing PSR B1919+21 waveforms. Update:
The model made it to London Science Museum! "3D: printing the future"
http://science-museum-3d-printing.tumblr.com/post/64208301940/from-left-to-right-pen-holder-white-donated-by Update:
The model from the Processing sketch wasn't manifold and i currently saw no way to improve it. Thus i rewrote the sketch in order to produce DXF files and extruded them with OpenSCAD. Details and Processing Sketch:
http://i.document.m05.de/2013/05/23/joy-divisions-unknown-pleasures-printed-in-3d/

Update:
The print should works now. Will test it next week. I printed the thing with MakerWare with white PLA on Makerbot Replicator. MakerBot's Slicer results were defect. Skeinforge worked quite well. There are still errors in the print which i think are maybe Replicator's plunger's fault.

description.text: Protector para ZMR250 con motres cobra 2204

Hobyking lipo tester 6s keychain

Funda protectora para medidor de baterias lipo de Hobyking
It is a can that hooks to your belt. Self explanatory.

Store you cables (e.g. LAN cables) sorted on the wall.

The model can be modified with OpenSCAD. The number of slots, the size of the prongs, the size of the backplate and the position of the holes can be changed.

I printed the model lying like in the image with a brim. I also used support structures for the holes, but they should not be necessary.

I used the Ultimaker 2 with PLA.

contour_radius = 2

This is for smaller ellipses than can be made with my other ellipsograph, it also has a larger range of ratios of major/minor axes. For a bigger one, you can scale it up, print it 100% infill and then just cancel the print, when it gets thick enough( 3mm seems to be plenty).

There are two versions, my first attempt, with gears made using simple arcs, and the second version, with "true" involute gears. Testing show that they both work fine.

Credit to user "ElicaTeam" on Youtube for inspiring this.

I just added 3 more ellipsographs that make a set that should nest together nicely for storage.

(Note: The nesting ellipsographs don't have any tolerances for printing, so they don't work as well as the first two that I posted.)
This is cut in 3mm MDF

The little RepRap style frame (which is actually pretty little compared to the Huxley it is derived from :) is nothing else but a desktop holder for my good old Galaxy Tab.  
The idea was to take the vertices used for a normal 3D printer a scale them down to fit M3 or M4 threaded rods.  
The hard work was done by Adrian Bowyer and JeanMarc Giacalone, who created the design of their Huxley models, RepRapPro (the source I used) and eMaker, respectively.  
I just added 2 clams to support the device.

Print either the M3 or M4 plate.
I would recommend M3 for smartphones and M4 for tablets, for stability reasons ;)
Print also a set of clams (feel free to combine the plates as you like :)
Establish the dimensions for the frame, keeping in mind that the sides for equilateral triangles. Get the threaded rods from your preferred hardware store and cut them according to your design. I used a full 1 m rod, and cut out of it 9 pieces of as equal as humanly possible length.
Have some 36 Mx nuts (and optionally the same number of washers) to assemble the frame, and a couple of M3x16 screws, with their nuts (and washers if you choose this option) to attach the clams.
Then view the images or just use your imagination to assemble everything.
Please note that there will be still enough holes available for different other purposes :D
